results.title: Dark angel
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Samuel Goldwyn and Sidney A. Franklin
results.brief_description: Set against the backdrop of a World War I ravaged England, this superbly acted romantic drama is a true classic. Merle Oberon is a revelation as a reformed vamp torn between two men - Herbert Marshall and Frederic March, the latter having returned from the war blinded. The script was adapted by Lillian Hellman from the play by Guy Bolton (a.k.a R. B. Trevelyan).

results.title: Darby's rangers = The Young invaders
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Martin Rackin and William Wellman
results.brief_description: In his first starring film role James Garner plays Colonel William Darby, an Army man in charge of organizing a group of rangers to be deployed in activities in Italy and Northern Africa. The film is chiefly presented in two parts - the preparation of the rangers, and their deployment in live action. Cast includes Etchika Choureau, Jack Warden and Edward Byrnes.

results.title: Danzon
results.creator_credit: Instituto Mexicano de Cinematografia, Tabasco Films, Television Espanola, Jorge Sanchez and Maria Novaro
results.brief_description: A light-hearted romantic tale about thirty-something Julia (Maria Rojo), a telephone operator and single mother of a 15-year-old daughter living in Mexico City whose passion is dancing the “danzon”, a ballroom dance with its origins in Haiti and which spread across to Cuba during the mid-1800s, finally finding its way to Mexico several years later. Mexico in fact celebrated the 100th anniversary of the danzon in the 1990s. Sensual and seductive, danzon expresses the unspoken relationship which exists between the dancing partners, where “the man commands and the woman obeys; the man seduces and the woman shines” and for Julia, when Carmelo (Daniel Rergis), her suave and elegant dancing partner of ten years, mysteriously disappears one night, life suddenly becomes meaningless. Julia sets out determinedly to find Carmelo, following a trail of clues to Vera Cruz where she encounters an eclectic mix of new friends including a motherly hotel manager with an acerbic tongue, a prostitute with a young baby, and a transvestite named Susy (Tito Vasconcelos). This journey of self-discovery, of old loves and new loves, twists and turns gently to the tune of the rhythmic Mexican music and the sensually tantalising dancing of the danzon. Maria Novaro (Lola, 1989) is one of Mexico’s most successful women film directors and is not only renowned for her feminist approach but is also considered an “expressionist” director for the use of colors as an important feature in her filmmaking. “Danzon” appeared in the Cannes Film Festival Official Selection for 1991. Cast also includes Carmen Salinas, Margarita Isabel, Victor Carpinteiro, Cheli Godinez. Original music by Agustin Lara, Pepe Luis, Felipe Perez, Consuelo Velazquez.

results.title: Danube interlude
results.creator_credit: Grainger Maynard, MTV HUngary, Australian Television Network and Greg Grainger
results.brief_description: This is compelling viewing, documenting a communist country as it undergoes profound changes. The program traces the breakdown of the communist system, watching Soviet soldiers withdraw for the first time since the Popular Uprising of 1956. “Danube interlude” shows Hungary at its most majestic, from a gentle trip down the Danube River to a ride on the famous Lippizan horses in the Bukk National Park.

results.title: Danton
results.brief_description:
The clash between warmly idealistic Danton and the coldly pragmatic Robespierre over the way the French revolution should go. ‘Danton’, is a film of highly dramatic power, at once a mature study of the revolutionary mentality and an absorbing intellectual spectacle. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1982 ; French Academy of Cinema 1983 (Cesar): best director for Andrzej Wajda ; British Academy Awards 1983: best foreign film. The film’s power derives from a series of contrasts between Danton and Robespierre on the level of characterisation and staging as much as ideology. The conflict is most evident when the two men confront each other’s claustrophobic and enclosed spaces, particularly during the aborted supper in Danton’s private apartment. In such scenes the theatricality of the dialogue, rendered all the more artificial by the dubbing of Pszoniak, is at odds with Depardieu’s more relaxed and gestural performance, which recalls the more enigmatic power of the silent cinema. The political conflict between the two is underlined not just by the contrast in styles of performance, but also by Wajda’s mise en scene, so that Danton’s clothes and rooms are red, Robespierre’s blue. This simple colour scheme is complemented by the use of white, which symbolises revolutionary purity and completes the republican tricolour.” Reference: Guy Austin. ‘Contemporary French cinema: an introduction’. Manchester University Press, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Margaret Menegoz ; director, Andrzej Wajda ; writer, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Igor luther ; music, Jean Podromides.
Cast: Gerard Depardieu, Wojtek Pszoniak, Patrice Chereau, Roger Planchon, Andrzej Seweryn, Angela Winkler, Jacques Villeret, Roland Blanche, Boguslaw Linda.

results.title: Danton
results.creator_credit: Margaret Menegoz, Barbara Pec-Slesicka and Andrzej Wajda
results.brief_description: Danton, a film of highly dramatic power, at once a mature study of the revolutionary mentality and an absorbing intellectual spectacle. “L’Incorruptible” Robespierre holds fast to the ideals of the French Revolution as it turns into a reign of terror. Tired of the bloodshed, Danton pleads for a negotiated peace with the enemies on France’s borders. Both are idealists. Both are right. Both are doomed. Stars Gerard Depardieu as Danton.

results.title: Dans les Caves du Fort D'ivry
results.brief_description:
This documentary made for television is part of a series about the treasures of the cinematheques. This episode deals specifically with the Army film archives held in the vaults of the Ivry Fort (outside Paris), whose aim is to preserve the audio-visual memory of all wars.

Credits: Director, Rene-Jean Bouyer.

results.title: Dans la vie (K)
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Rene Jodoin and Pierre Veilleux
results.brief_description: The film animator gives vivid expression to his own memories of a child’s first encounter with elementary school - at the tender age when grown-ups appear ten feet tall, a monster lurks in every corridor and the very walls have eyes. Feeling, but not understanding the regimentation imposed on him, the child seeks, in spite of it all, to be himself. Awards: Toronto; Oberhausen.

results.title: Danny the champion of the world
results.brief_description: This Roald Dahl story is set in a small English village in 1955. Danny (Samuel Irons) and his widowed father (Jeremy Irons) devise a plot, supported by their close-knit community, to save hundreds of pheasants from being shot on the estate of their wealthy neighbour Hazel (Robbie Coltrane). While carrying out their plan, the community learns of Hazel’s intention to redevelop the town. Also stars Michael Hordern, Cyril Cusack and Lionel Jeffries.

results.title: Danny's egg (K)
results.creator_credit: PBL Productions, Michael Midlam and David Haythornthwaite
results.brief_description: The story of Danny, a young boy living in an Australian country town, who discovers an emu’s egg and sets about ensuring that it hatches. Danny is thwarted by the school michief-maker but manages to incubate the egg. Provides a delightful look at the diverse skills required of the country teacher and the lifestyle of country schoolchildren. Written by David Haythornthwaite from a story by Jim Badger. Cast includes Ken Talbot as Danny. Suitable for primary school level.
